newsitem.title: UNITED NATIONS: OAU chief urges African nominees for top U.N. post.
newsitem.headline: OAU chief urges African nominees for top U.N. post.

text.p: The Organisation of African Unity chairman has urged African leaders to propose candidates for the post of U.N. secretary-general to ensure Boutros Boutros-Ghali is succeeded by another African if he remains blocked from a second term.

Cameroonian President Paul Biya's letter to African heads of state appeared to break a deadlock that followed the U.S. veto of Boutros-Ghali on Nov. 19, when Africans remained reluctant to submit alternative candidates while the Egyptian diplomat's name was still in play.

In the letter, obtained by Reuters, Biya said it seemed time, in order to preserve Africa's chances for a second term as U.N. secretary-general, for African states to present the names of other qualified candidates jointly with that of Boutros-Ghali.
Urging swift action, he said countries could inform the president of the U.N. Security Council directly of their nominations, while also keeping him informed.
A number of African diplomats have been mentioned as possible candidates for the post of secretary-general when Boutros-Ghali's current five-year term expires on Dec. 31.

But none has been officially submitted since Boutros-Ghali's candidacy has not been withdrawn, although the United States has vowed to keep blocking him on the grounds that the United Nations needs new leadership to carry out reforms.
